properties.media:imagetext:
up up and away
arthur fiedler
boston pops
The final section of every Boston Pops concert program features show medleys and symphonic
treatments of popular hits of the day. It is always a matter of keen interest to the Pops' audiences
just what golden nuggets Maestro Fiedler has mined from the vast field of so-called "pop" music.
The present collection represents some of the choice hits from current pop groups, movies and shows.
The title tune won the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences' accolade as the best song
of 1967. In his arrangement Richard Hayman has caught the right free-wheeling spirit for the Pops
take-off. André Previn's rhythmically sophisticated and melodically tranquiliz
movie valley or the Dous is followed oy anotner movie ute tune, ine irrepressidie beorsy olf.
It is interesting to hear how easily the writing Beatles' (John Lennon and Paul McCartney) melodic
inspiration, Yesterday, leads into the one purely classical piece on the record. Although everyone
may not be familiar with the title Andante from Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 21, we will wager that
no one who has seen the haunting film "Elvira Madigan" will soon forget it. The present recording of
of which is a delicate combination of what we now know as piano and harpsichord tone. We are
indebted to Newton Wavland for his excellent performance or the solo part and to rine Manol
Junior College of Brookline, Massachusetts, for the loan of the instrument.
A truly stunning performance of the brash title tune from the Broadway smash "Cabaret" opens
Side 2. Then the Beatles. who have made such a tremendous contribution through their wilung to
raising the level of quality in popular music, are again saluted with Michelle.
Love Is Blue and the affecting theme from one of France's most beautiful films, "A Man and a
Woman," bring us to A Lover's Concerto, which has a story all its own. I was hrst taken with the
tune when I heard Diana Ross and the Supremes' version of it. It sounded strangely familiar and
terribly appropriate for Boston Pops treatment. When I played it for Arthur Fiedler he immediately
knew whw: "Ot course, that is a Minuet from .. bach's Musical Notebook for Anna Magdalena.
And so, indeed, it is! A rather apt example of the increasing influence that classical music has in
tne pop nierature
Since Lara's Theme has become one of the all-time favorites with Boston Pops audiences, It Is
perhaps appropriate that we close with this radiantly romantic strain from "Doctor Zhivago."
-PETER DELLHEIM
side 1
Up, Up and Away
